turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: He doesn't miss a trick, does he?

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: What a jerk -- and like nobody knows who he really is!

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: He's Lance Hunt! Just take off the glasses -- and it's him!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: There's a vague similarity.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: A vague similarity? IT'S THE SAME GUY!

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: We need a break, that's all! Nobody'd ever heard of him until he busted Casanova Frankenstein!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: But look at him... and look at us.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Why do they always fill stuff these things so full you can't pull 'em out without ripping 'em!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: I lost another fork tonight. She's getting suspicious, I know it.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: So why don't you just tell her!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Because I can't! Okay? She wouldn't understand!

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Nah.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Roy, when was the last time you had an actual date?

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: What does it matter? Women just want to control you -- and talk about their feelings. They want to know why you're angry all the time -- and what can they can do to help -- so you tell them there's nothing -- nothing -- just leave me alone -- but they bug you and they bug you and they bug you -- until you just can't stand it anymore! -- so you finally open up -- you pop like a blister -- and it all comes spewing out -- all your emotions -- your feelings -- your fears -- all of it!  And then they dump you.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: So you're chicken?

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Who's chicken?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Maybe you should try a more romantic approach.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Like what? Cutting off my own ear?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Or flowers.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: See ya tomorrow.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: I saw him go in -- and he didn't come out!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: But we don't know for sure it's the same guy.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Wait!... Look!

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: The who?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: The most vicious gang of thugs this city ever produced. Twenty years ago they were Casanova's personal bodyguard. But after he was busted they crawled into the woodwork.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Well they've crawled back out.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: I'm soaked.  Oh great.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Shhh.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Maybe she's right.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Are you serious? This is the break we've been waiting for!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Agents?

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Archenemies! Casanova isn't just a criminal -- he's a supervillain. Stopping him could be our ticket to fame, fortune -- and babes!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: But there's only three of us, and he's got the entire brotherhood of evil at his disposal.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Then maybe it's time for us to form our own brotherhood... a brotherhood of righteous, crime fighting, skull cracking, Disco Boy bashing, warriors of the night!

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Sounds good.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: No one's sure that he actually exists, but they say he can be contacted by leaving a message on a crumpled up napkin at the Tacky Taco down by the bus station.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Maybe there was traffic.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Who are we kidding? No one's gonna show. We're living in a fantasy!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Roy, remember, it is all within your power. The only thing that's in your way... is you.

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Oh shut up.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Roy --

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Go dance with your mother, Jeffrey!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: So where's the art?

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: He hasn't stolen it yet.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Come on.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: He's turned into a completely normal person!

turns.speaker: FURIOUS
turns.text: Normal. What's normal? Does normal exist? And if it did, how would we know it?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: But... only when no one is looking.

turns.speaker: INVISIBLE BOY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: So you're only invisible... to yourself?

turns.speaker: INVISIBLE BOY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: So you're only invisible, when absolutely no one is looking at you?

turns.speaker: INVISIBLE BOY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: INVISIBLE BOY
turns.text: The Obliterators!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: The Eradicators!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Firepower costs money.

turns.speaker: INVISIBLE BOY
turns.text: Anybody got any?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Yes, Obie-wan.

turns.speaker: INVISIBLE BOY
turns.text: Hey... he's gone.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: You guys going to a costume party?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: We're superheroes.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Really? Like Captain Amazing?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Are you famous?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: So you're like... struggling superheroes?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: We prefer to think of ourselves as unsung... I am the Blue Raja, Master of Silverware...

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Wow.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: And these are my associates, the Shoveler.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Usually a superpower is a magical endowment or a great skill. In his case, it's entirely emotional.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: So what can I get you?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Burgers all around.  Medium.  Rare.  Raw.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Here you go.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Ow.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Maybe you guys ought to forget this Superhero stuff and join Kiwanis or something.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Jeffrey!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Oh hi, Mom.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What are you doing in the silver drawer?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Looking for... the TV Guide.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: It's on the television.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Of course. I'm such a fool... Thanks, Mummy.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Jeffrey, YOU THIEF!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Mother... it's not what you think!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: And why are you wearing that silly costume?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Because... I'M A SUPERHERO!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Oh, Mother, I'm sorry. I know how much you wanted me to be a doctor or a lawyer with a family -- but it's just not who I am!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But... the silverware?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: I use it... to fight evil.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Jeffrey... this is wonderful.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: It is?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I always knew that you were special.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: You did?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Ever since you were a little boy...  Come with me.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Oh, who gives a damn who he is? I can't take this anymore. Night after night we're on the streets, busting our humps -- and for what?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: We take the licks and he gets the chicks.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: How long do you have to chase a dream before you realize it's not gonna happen?

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: And Mister Furious... His anger is his power.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: She likes you.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Definitely.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Ask her out.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: This is bad.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Who are they?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: The Disco Boys.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: We may be getting in over our heads here.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: This looks like a job for Superman --

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Or Batman --

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Or both.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Don't crunch the leaves.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Be a Mohican.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Be a Mohican.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Do we have to?

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: I got this cousin. He's a real doofus, but he claims he can become invisible.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: And there's the Sphinx.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: The who?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: He's a legendary masked Mexican crime fighting superwrestler and master of the machete.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: And a social life.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Yeah, but how do we get to them?

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: To us!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Whatever our name is.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Are you sure he's still lives here?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Are you sure he's still alive?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: But, Doc... where's the machine guns?

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: The bazookas?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Twenty years ago all the major hoodlums of this city were united into one great brotherhood of evil, and Casanova was their king.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Crime was rampant. It wasn't safe to stay in your home.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: He busted Casanova and sent the crooks packing.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: And this has been a pretty nice place to live ever since.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Maybe it's time we checked that place out.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: But how do we get in?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: That was too close.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: But we gotta find out what's going on in there.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: We're outnumbered twenty to one.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: It's suicide.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Oh no.

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Great timing!

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: It's time.

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: With or without him, we gotta go!

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: We've got lift off!

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: May the forks be with us!

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Where am I going?

turns.speaker: RAJA
turns.text: Through there!

turns.speaker: SHOVELER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: It is a thing entirely unknown in diplomacy, that one government should assume a right to dictate to another, who is upon terms of equality, the conditions on which she should conduct her commerce; and, assuming such a right, second it by threatening language, in case of non-compliance.

turns.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
turns.text: But, Your Majesty, the very substance of the Tilsit treaty was that you should join the Continental Blockade, boycott English goods, suspend all commercial dealings with her, and be France's ally.  Nothing more is being asked than to comply with the treaty.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: My dear Caulaincourt, agreements can endure only when they allow both sides to live.  Napoleon may believe it is necessary to injure England but, before that, he must realize it is necessary for him to allow his friends to live.  He cannot expect me to tell my nobles they must ruin themselves so that he can bring England to her knees -- and I'm afraid that is what it has come to.

turns.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
turns.text: I can appreciate what Your Majesty is saying but the Emperor has staked everything on this policy.  He has no other way to attack England, and no one knows more than Your Majesty how his overtures for peace have been rejected.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: It's a fine thing to establish policies but, when they don't work, they must be reconsidered.  Granted that you have hurt England, but she is still on her feet.  And to seal off her trade with Europe, what has it cost you?  You have had to rule with an iron hand.  You have turned friends into enemies.  And even at that, the result has only been partly effective.  You have never been able to stop the extensive cheating, smuggling and corruption -- even of your own officials.  But I should think the situation in Spain, alone, would give your policy a minus balance.  You have had to commit a quarter of a million of your best troops against the guerrillas, with no victory in sight. And you have given England a dangerous foothold on the Continent, for her armies.

turns.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
turns.text: I am in no position to debate this with you, Your Majesty, but can you imagine what a blow it will be to the Emperor if you should now desert his cause?  It would mean nothing less than victory for England.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: My dear Caulaincourt, you have no idea of how compromised my own position has become since Tilsit.  I am blamed by the army for the military disaster at Austerlitz and Friedland, by the nobility for ruining their trade with England, by the merchants who must accept French foods at unprofitable prices, and by the nation for allowing Napoleon to dictate Russian policy.

turns.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
turns.text: Your Majesty knows my affection for him is deep and genuine, and goes far beyond my official role as Ambassador.  But I would be remiss in my feelings for you, and in my responsibility to the Emperor, if I did not say that it is entirely possible that the Emperor will view your refutation of the terms of the Treaty of Tilsit, as the first step in the exchange of a French alliance for an English one -- with all the dangers that might entail.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I have given a great deal of thought to that possibility, and I am prepared to face it.  If it should come to war, and I presume that is what you are alluding to, I would rather have war with the Emperor than my own people.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: I hope you will forgive me, Your Majesty, for requesting an audience at such a late hour, but I have traveled all the way from Moscow to see you, on a matter which cannot wait.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Very well, General, what is it you wish to say?

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: Your Majesty, I have been advised that you have received a letter from Napoleon, offering a peace treaty, and that you have decided to accept it.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I have decided to accept the principle of a negotiation; the terms are not established.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: If I may, Your Majesty, I would like to offer a dissenting opinion.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: General Kutusov, feel free to say whatever you like.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: I believe I am right in saying that, before the fire, the country had grown weary of the war, and there were few who were interested in continuing the battle.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Proceed.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: But, since the fire, a completely new spirit has been aroused in the nation.  The French have become an army of criminals, against whom Russia must be avenged, against whom she is now prepared to fight to the death.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You know, General Kutusov, there is a very strong possibility that the fire was not started by Napoleon's troops but was organized under the orders of Rostopchin's secret police.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: I have heard that story but I do not believe it.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Rostopchin is a fanatic and he is capable of anything -- however, it doesn't affect what we are talking about.  Please go on.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: The point I was trying to make is that I think it is reasonable to say that Your Majesty would not find himself under unbearable pressure, if he decided to make peace with the Emperor, at least at this time.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: For the sake of your argument, let us say that is correct.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: Well, has Your Majesty considered what Napoleon's alternatives might be, if you simply chose to ignore his note?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes, General Kutusov, I daresay that this has been considered and discussed at great length.  Napoleon would simply spend the winter in Moscow and continue the campaign in the spring.  Another lesser possibility might be to march on St. Petersburg now, although there is some doubt that he has the strength to do this, until he refits his army.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: You have my absolute assurance, Your Majesty, that Napoleon does not have the strength to attack St. Petersburg now -- his army is exhausted and ill-supplied, and he would be defeated if he attempted that.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I will accept your assurance, but I'm afraid I don't see your point.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: Forgive me, Your Majesty, I am about to make it.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Ah, yes -- proceed.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: The point is that I don't think Napoleon will sit in Moscow until the spring!  I don't think he can afford to.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Well, that is a very interesting idea, General Kutusov, but I can assure you that Napoleon is no beginner at this.  Whatever analysis you have done on this situation, I am sure that he has gone over the same ground.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: I have no doubt that he has, Your Majesty, but does he have any strong moves from which to choose?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Well, one thing immediately comes to mind, if what you are saying is true -- he would merely withdraw his army from Moscow and return to Poland for the winter.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: Your Majesty has grasped the outlines of his problem in much less time than it took me.  This is a crucial point -- and it is a political one, which Your Majesty will be in a far better position to answer than I.  Can Napoleon afford to abandon Moscow without signing even the preliminaries of a peace treaty with you?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I must confess he would look a bit silly, fighting his way to Moscow and turning right around again.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: Perhaps it would be even more serious than that, Your Majesty. His European confederation is held together by some very slender threads.  Your Majesty knows even better than I that Austria and Prussia are very doubtful allies, and the Emperor has reason enough to fear that they will turn on him, at the first sign of weakness.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Proceed.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: If I can presume to go into the Emperor's mind, I believe that he has based his entire campaign strategy on obtaining a peace treaty after the fall of Moscow.  When Vienna fell, there was a peace treaty.  When Berlin fell, another treaty.  That has always been the rules of the game.  But what is he to do now if no treaty is forth- coming?  He knows that beyond Moscow, there is nothing, and that, if he withdraws, there remains only a fall into emptiness.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What do you think Napoleon will do?

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: I, personally, am convinced that he will withdraw his army from Moscow, and attempt to establish himself in Poland for the winter.  In the end, he will not allow himself to be cut off from Paris.  But I believe that if he is offered any encouragement, by Your Majesty, he will postpone this decision as long as possible. He is a gambler and he will trust to his luck.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: If he withdraws his army in good order, it will be a serious political defeat.  But, if he should be caught on the move, with his army, in the full grip of winter, then it will be a catastrophe.  If Your Majesty can prolong his hopes for a treaty by silence, be deceit, by any means, for another month, thus postponing his departure, then the graves of his army are already dug in the soil of Russia.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: General Kutusov, I would like to call a meeting of my cabinet tomorrow morning and have you present this idea to them.  I think it has merit and is worthy of consideration.

turns.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
turns.text: I am at your disposal, Your Majesty.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And, what a great pleasure it is, indeed, to meet you, Alexander.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: And, what a delightful idea!

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Ah -- you approve?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I think it's absolutely charming.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I'm glad you like it.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Whatever suggested the idea to you?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I shall tell you in the strictest confidence -- when I was a boy, I had a passion for rafts, and never had the opportunity to build one.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You can always tell at a glance whether retreating infantry are being pursed by cavalry, because they hurry along and keep turning around and looking back.  When they are retreating before infantry, they merely trudge along, head down.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Fascinating!  Tell me, leaving aside the question of grand strategy, for the moment, what would you say is the single most difficult tactical skill to master?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Without a doubt, to estimate the enemy's strength on the battlefield. This is something that is only acquired by experience and instinct. At Jena, there were as many opinions about strength of the enemy as there were generals present.  Murat said there were 50,000, preparing to attack.  Berthier said there were no more than 25,000, about to withdraw. "Berthier sees only what is in the open," Murat said.  "But don't forget there is a second force hidden in the forest."  And so it would always go, each of them would judge things according to his own ability, character and state of mind, at the moment.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Ah, my dear Napoleon, sometimes I feel that I am not really an Emperor as you are.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I know absolutely nothing of war -- and I am still totally dependent upon my generals.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Yes -- who spoke up?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I did, sir.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Yes, Captain?  Have you anything you wish to say?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, with all due respect, I do Citizen Barras.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Please...

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: May I come to the map?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Ah, my dear friend, come in, come in.  Please sit down.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I'm sorry, I was at the theater and I didn't receive your note until I returned to my hotel.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Thank you for coming.  Would you care for a drink?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: I don't have to tell you of our latest difficulties.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Things are quite serious, I should say.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: We expect an attack on the Convention tomorrow morning, at daybreak, and I have been placed in charge of its defense.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What do you have in mind?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: To be perfectly honest, I haven't the vaguest idea.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Are you serious?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: I don't even know whether a defense is possible.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What forces do you have at your disposal?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: About 5,000 troops.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Cavalry?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: The 21st Dragoons, about two or three-hundred troopers.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Any cannon?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: There are none here.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Where are they?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Well, I believe there are at least 30 guns at Sablons.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You could have them here by daybreak.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Is this enough to oppose 40,000 men?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Properly arranged, yes.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: These are odds of 8 to 1.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: The numbers are not particularly relevant.  You are not up against soldiers -- this is a mob, and they will run as soon as things become sufficiently unpleasant.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Would you be prepared to handle this for me?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Are you proposing to transfer command to me?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: In every practical sense, yes, but, officially, of course, I would have to retain command.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Fair enough.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: I must be honest with you.  I first approached three generals more senior than yourself, and they all very prudently sent excuses.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I'm not insulted.

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: You realize what is at stake?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Our lives, the revolution, my career?

turns.speaker: BARRAS
turns.text: Look, let me be completely open with you, I have a carriage and an escort waiting for me, and I have a great deal of money outside of France. Unless we stand a very good chance of carrying this off, I am prepared to call it quits right now.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, Belliard, what's this?  What are you doing here?  Where is the enemy?

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: They are at the gates of Paris, sire.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And where is the army?

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: It is on this road, sire, following me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And who is defending Paris?

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: Paris is evacuated, sire.  The enemy is to enter at nine o'clock tomorrow morning.  The National Guard is on duty at the gates.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Paris has surrendered?!  I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: Unhappily, it is true, sire.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: But where are my wife and son? What's become of them?  Where is Marmont?  Where is Mortier?

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: The Empress, your son and the whole court left two days ago for Rambouillet.  Marshals Mortier and Marmont are probably still in Paris, completing the arrangements.

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: But, sire, Your Majesty would lay Paris open to being sacked.  The enemy is outside the gates with more than 120,000 men.  Besides this, I left the city under the terms of a treaty and I am forbidden to reenter Paris.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: A treaty?  Don't be ridiculous. What treaty is this?  Who made it? Who has been giving orders?

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: I don't know the details of the treaty, sire, Marshal Mortier sent me word of its having been agreed to, and he said that I was to take the army and make for Fontainebleau.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: But who made this treaty?

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: I believe it was arranged by Marshals Mortier and Marmont.  I must explain to you that we have had no orders all day.  Each marshal has been keeping his own position.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Who sent my wife and son out of Paris?

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: I don't know, sire.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And where is Joseph?

turns.speaker: BELLIARD
turns.text: I don't know what has happened to Prince Joseph.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What cowardice!  What treason! Joseph has ruined everything.  How could they all lose their heads. They knew I was coming up fast. Victory was just within grasp. Come, come, turn your troops around, General Belliard.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Josephine dead -- how unbelievable! How impossible it is to believe it. She was always physically so strong -- she was never ill a day in her life.

turns.speaker: BERTRAND
turns.text: It is a terrible shock.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: But did she have the best doctors? Wasn't there any chance at all to save her?

turns.speaker: BERTRAND
turns.text: I don't know, sire -- she had the Tsar's personal physician.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: She should have had Larrey or Corvisart.  They might have saved her... But why didn't anyone even write to me?  Can you believe that no one even bothered to write to me? Would you have believed that I should read such news in a newspaper?  How incredible!

turns.speaker: BERTRAND
turns.text: That is incredible.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Ah, my poor Josephine.  She was the most alluring, most glamorous creature I have ever known -- a woman in every sense of the word, and she had the kindest heart in the world.  She may have been a liar and a spendthrift, but she had something that was irresistible -- she was a women to her very fingertips... How impossible it is to believe that she is dead.

turns.speaker: BERTRAND
turns.text: I have never heard an unkind word about her spoken.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I suppose I might blame her for opening her house to the men most responsible to my downfall, but how can I?  She was on her own again, she had to look after her own affairs, and how can one blame her for having her head turned by the attention of Kings?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Who is there?

turns.speaker: BERTRAND
turns.text: Bertrand, sire.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I have just had the most vivid... dream... about Josephine.

turns.speaker: BERTRAND
turns.text: Yes, sire?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: She was sitting there... and it was as if I had last seen her only the night before... She hadn't changed -- she was still the same -- still completely devoted to me... and she told me we were going to see each other again and, never again, leave each other... She has promised me. Did you see her?

turns.speaker: BERTRAND
turns.text: No, sire... I was asleep.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I wanted to kiss her, but she didn't want to kiss me... She slipped away, the moment I wanted to take her in my arms.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Read it back.

turns.speaker: BOURRIENNE
turns.text: To Joseph Bonaparte -- Dear Joseph, I have been informed by my wife of the cold and spiteful treatment she has been receiving at the hands of my family, since my departure.  I am also informed that you have refused to pay over to her any of the money I left with you expressly for this purpose.  Must you, too, take this opportunity during my absence to indulge the petty jealousies of the Bonaparte family?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Oh, shit, that's not right.

turns.speaker: BOURRIENNE
turns.text: General Bonaparte?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Come back in an hour.

turns.speaker: BOURRIENNE
turns.text: Excuse me, General Bonaparte, but I believe this is an extremely urgent matter, requiring your immediate attention.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Come in.

turns.speaker: BOURRIENNE
turns.text: This dispatch has just arrived from Aboukir, marked highest priority, for General Bonaparte's eyes only.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Let me see it.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I believe you are acquainted with my brother, Joseph Bonaparte, and my aide, Major Junot.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Yes, sir, I had the honor of meeting them on the trip from Paris.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Captain Charles, I believe you are one of General Le Clerc's aides-de- camp.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Yes, sir, I am.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Was it he who assigned you to command the escort which accompanied Madame Bonaparte's coach?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Was the trip normal in every respect?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Did any difficulties of any kind arise during the trip?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: No, sir, none at all.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Then, you have my thanks, Captain Charles, for safely escorting Madame Bonaparte to Milan, and you may consider your assignment completed.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You will return to Paris tomorrow and you will carry my compliments and thanks to General Le Clerc for assigning such an excellent officer to carry out a responsibility which has meant so much to myself and to Madame Bonaparte.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Thank you, sir.  I will do that.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You may go, Captain Charles.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: Yes, sir?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: A glass of champagne, please.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: Yes, sir.  I hope you will excuse me for asking, General Bonaparte, but are you Corsican?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, I am.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: I thought so, I noticed your name when you were announced.  I'm Corsican too -- my name is Arena.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Oh -- where do you come from?

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: Bastia -- and you?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Ajaccio.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: Have you been back recently?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I haven't been there for three years.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: I haven't been back for ten years. Is your family still there?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: No, they're living in Nice now.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: That's a nice city.  This is your first time here, isn't it?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, as a matter of fact, it is.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: You don't know many of Citizen Barras' friends, do you?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Ah-hh, no.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: I thought not.  I noticed you by yourself, all night.

turns.speaker: CORSICAN
turns.text: Just a minute, General.  Listen, don't let them fool you with all their grand la-de-da.  They've all made their money from the war -- mostly from crooked war contracts. They say Citizen Barras has put away millions.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I see...

turns.speaker: DIDIER
turns.text: Hello there, Picart.

turns.speaker: PICART
turns.text: Ah, Didier -- you are alive.

turns.speaker: DIDIER
turns.text: Why are you carrying the dog?

turns.speaker: PICART
turns.text: His paws are frozen and he cannot walk.

turns.speaker: DIDIER
turns.text: When you eat him, may I have some?

turns.speaker: PICART
turns.text: My God -- don't you recognize Mouton -- our regimental dog?  I would rather eat Cossack.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: My God...!  What time is it?

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: Four o'clock.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: My God, what a fire!

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: When did it start?

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: The first reports came in at about ten.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Why didn't you wake me then?

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: At first, it hardly seemed more than a routine fire.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: How did it spread so quickly?

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: It is the work of incendiaries.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I told Mortier that he would answer with his life for any looting.

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: Our troops have no part in this.  It has been started by the Russians!

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Impossible, I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: We have already captured a dozen incendiaries, convicts, released just two days ago.  They said they were acting under orders of the secret police.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: But to start a fire like this in five hours -- how is it possible? It would take a carefully organized plan, tons of combustibles and hundreds of people.

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: From what we can tell, there are hundreds of agents, all over the city.  The combustibles seem to have been carefully placed beforehand, and all the fire-engines have been removed from the city.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: My God -- this could be very bad for us... very bad, indeed.

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: Good heavens, Ambassador -- what has happened?

turns.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
turns.text: Ah, good evening, my dear Duroc. I'm afraid I've been out hunting and I have had a rather bad fall.

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: Indeed you have, Ambassador.  Have you sent for a doctor?

turns.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
turns.text: Yes, I have, and I hope you will forgive me, Duroc, but unless your visit is extremely urgent, I shall have to ask you to excuse me until tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: I beg your indulgence, Ambassador, but it is.

turns.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: The Emperor has decided to marry your Archduchess, Marie-Louise.

turns.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: Earlier this afternoon, the Emperor refused the hand of the Grand Duchess Anna, of Russia, and, as I'm sure you can appreciate, he is quite able to change his mind again.  For the Emperor, to choose a wife, is only a matter of minutes.

turns.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
turns.text: But this is not a matter which can be settled tonight, surely?

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: No one can say how the Emperor's thoughts work, Ambassador, and unless we move quickly, he might change his mind again.

turns.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
turns.text: But, my dear Duroc, how can I act without guidance from Vienna?  I haven't the slightest idea of how the Emperor Francis might feel about this.

turns.speaker: DUROC
turns.text: May I suggest that we can prepare and sign the agreement, between ourselves, subject to the approval of the two Emperors.  Believe me, my dear friend, your Archduchess, Marie-Louis, may very well hold, in her hands, the future of our two countries.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Good morning, Citizen de Beauharnais.

turns.speaker: EUGENE
turns.text: Good morning, sir.  Are you General Bonaparte?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I am, Citizen.  Is your mother Madame Josephine de Beauharnais?

turns.speaker: EUGENE
turns.text: Yes, sir.  Are you acquainted with her?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I have met her.  What is your business with me?

turns.speaker: EUGENE
turns.text: I believe you issued an order that all citizens of Paris must hand over any weapons that they have in their possession.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: That is correct.

turns.speaker: EUGENE
turns.text: This morning, a Lieutenant and three soldiers came to our house and asked if we had weapons.  I explained we had only my late father's sword, which, in fact, was not a weapon but only a keepsake of memory.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: A sword is a weapon whatever else you might wish to use it for.

turns.speaker: EUGENE
turns.text: I told the Lieutenant my late father was General Alexander de Beauharnais, and asked if there was any consideration that might be given to his memory.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And he sent you to me?

turns.speaker: EUGENE
turns.text: He said no one had the authority to rescind the order except you.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Does your mother know you have come?

turns.speaker: EUGENE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, then, you have a lot of initiative, my young friend.

turns.speaker: EUGENE
turns.text: My father's sword means more to me than any other possession I have.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You realize, of course, that thousands of swords have been collected.  How do you expect me to find yours?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Ah, my dear Francis, what a genuine pleasure it is to meet you at last.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: I fear our meeting is long overdue... Napoleon.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I'm sorry that I am unable to offer you better hospitality, but this is the only place I have inhabited for the past month.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: You have made such excellent use of it; I should think you will hate to leave it.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Shall we move closer to the fire?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Yes -- an excellent idea.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Will Alexander be joining us soon?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: I very much doubt that he will.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: I'm afraid he has been rather upset by the outcome of the battle.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: But he asked me to say...  on his behalf... that your achievements have increased his...  admiration for you, and that he believes... your success is predestined by heaven...  and that his army...

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: My dear Francis, you do seem extremely uncomfortable.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: I'm afraid I am, just a bit.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Would you like some brandy?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I'll have the fire built up.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Thank you, Napoleon.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Francis, may I ask whether you wear warm winter underwear?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: No -- not as a rule.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Ah, well, that is the first rule of warfare.  You must wear long-sleeved and long-legged underwear.  You can never conjure up brilliancies with a cold bottom.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Good evening, sir.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Good evening, Mademoiselle.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: The weather is terrible, isn't it, sir?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, it is.  It must be one of the worst nights we have had this winter.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Yes, it must be.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You must be chilled to the bone, standing out of doors like this.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Yes, I am, sir.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Then what brings you out on such a night?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Well, one must do something to live, you know -- and I have an elderly mother who depends on me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Oh, I see... That must be a great burden.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: One must take life as it comes -- do you live in Lyon, sir?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: No, I'm only here on leave.  My regiment is at Valence.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Are you staying with a friend, sir?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: No... I have a... room... at the Hotel de Perrin.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Is it a nice warm room, sir?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, it must be a good deal warmer than it is here on the street.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Would you like to take me there, so that we can get warm, sir?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Uh-hh... yes, of course -- if you would like to go... there... but... I have very little money.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Do you have three francs, sir?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Br-rrr, these sheets are like ice.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry about that.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Lisette.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Only Lisette?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Lisette La Croix.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: That's a very nice name.  Where are you from?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Please, sir, come into bed or I shall die of a chill.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Oh, yes... of course.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I would like both of you to read this.  Please read it aloud.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: To Citizen General Bonaparte from one who does not wish to see him dishonored by his wife.  You should know, Citizen General, that your wife has taken a lover, one Captain Hippolyte Charles... undated and unsigned.
